> If we had a math class with a sqrt method, and we wanted to assert 
> that our method only handled non negative numbers, what is the 
> difference between:
> 
> assert n > 0 (JDK 1.4)
> 
> and
> 
> JUnit test
> 
> try {
>    Math.sqrt(-1);
> } catch (IllegalArgumentException) {
>    // ok - verified method throws proper exception
> }


The problem I see with the "assert" keyword in JDK1.4 is that it is only 
executed when the code is compiled and executed in "assert" mode.

In your case, n must _always_ be > 0 and not only when the code is 
compiled and executed in "assert" mode. There is no reason to use 
"assert" (use IllegalArgumentException instead)

"Similarly, assertions should not be used for argument checking in 
public methods" (assert guide)

Testing the method with a TestCase will ensure that the method _always_ 
acts like it should.  If your class is bullet-proof and handles every 
case possible, there is not need to use the "assert" keyword.

The only problem with tests is that you're only testing a small part of 
your entire application at a given time (a class at a time, using mock 
objects if necessary).  It can be really hard to test the application 
like it should be used (with all classes interacting with eachothers, 
with the GUI...).  Maybe the "assert" keyword can be used to test the 
unexpected when you're doing integration testing.

But I still have to find out the real value of the "assert" keyword.

Can anyone convince me?
